concern:
Not sure if anyone else feels this way but it can be a lonely journey in grad school especially because of the niche stresses, things we have to deal with. 

Created a group me that will hopefully foster some community for people to talk with one another and build some friendships or the very least camaraderie 

Here’s the link to join: You're invited to my new group 'Grad School Community' on GroupMe. Click here to join: https://groupme.com/join_group/86601776/iTupsbUn

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I hope you're doing well today. Feel free to share whatever's on your mind or anything you'd like to discuss.
Hey, thanks. I've been thinking a lot about how isolating grad school can be. It feels like everyone is in their own bubble, dealing with their own stresses, you know?
Therapist: That sounds really challenging. What has it been like for you managing these feelings of isolation while in grad school?
client: It's been tough, honestly. I feel like I'm constantly surrounded by people but still feel disconnected because everyone is so focused on their own stuff.
It sounds like you're feeling quite alone despite being around others. What impact do you think this sense of disconnection has on your experience in grad school and your goals?

client: It definitely makes it harder to stay motivated and focused, like I’m missing out on a support system that could help me push through. Sometimes it feels like I'm just going through the motions without really enjoying or getting the most out of the experience.

It sounds like having a support system is really important for you. Based on what you've shared, possible options could include joining a study group or finding a hobby outside of school to build connections. What are your thoughts on these, or do you have other ideas in mind?

Honestly, I’ve been trying to create a bit of community on my own by starting a GroupMe for grad students. It’s a small step, but I thought it could help bring people together who are feeling the same way. I'm also open to finding some hobbies outside of school, but I'm not sure where to start with that yet.

Starting a GroupMe sounds like a great initiative to build community. As for hobbies, you might consider trying out different activities to see what you enjoy, such as a local club or a class in something new. What first steps do you feel comfortable taking to explore these options, and how can you anticipate any challenges that might come up?

I'm thinking of attending a club meeting or maybe trying out a class I've been curious about. It feels a bit daunting to put myself out there, but I guess just taking small steps is key. I'll probably need to remind myself that it's okay to feel out of my comfort zone and to just go with the flow.

You've made some meaningful plans to address these feelings of disconnection by starting a GroupMe and considering new hobbies. Taking small steps like attending a club meeting or trying a new class can indeed be a rewarding way to explore connections and interests. It's understandable that stepping out of your comfort zone feels daunting, but it's great that you're reminding yourself it's okay to feel that way. Remember, this process is about taking one step at a time and allowing yourself the space to grow. And having that kind of awareness is a wonderful strength. How about setting a date to attend that first meeting or class? You got this, and I'm here to support you as you explore these new paths.
Thanks, I appreciate the encouragement. I'll look into some club schedules this week and see if I can find a class that fits. Just gotta take it one step at a time, right?
